Answers with Unsupervised Learning

A quick reminder of some possibilities with unsupervised learning.

Avishai M Tsur true
2021-11-23

Introduction

Unsupervised learning entails a set of tools that allows to gain insight regarding relationships and individual observations using unlabeled datasets. It is sometimes used as a pre-processor in a supervised learning pipeline as a tool for dimensionality reduction. The latter however, is outside the scope of this post.

A few important disclaimers

  • It is highly suggested to read the An Introduction to Statistical Learning chapter on Unsupervised Learning and also visit ISLR tidymodels Labs. Prior understanding of unsupervised learning is needed.
  • Mistakes happen all the time, even in this post.
  • Throughout this post, we will be using numerous r packages. I wish to thank all of their authors and contributors as well for making this analysis possible and much simpler.
  • This post is not to explain the theory, rather to show an implementation of unsupervised learning to real data.

Data source

We will use data from the TidyTuesday project. It originates from fastfoodnutrition.org and contains data on entrees from different fast-food restaurants.

food <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2018/2018-09-04/fastfood_calories.csv") %>% na.omit() %>% select(-cal_fat) %>% 
    distinct(item, .keep_all = T)

What questions can be answered with unsupervised learning?

  1. Who is most similar in general?
  2. Who is most similar to a specific observation? (also new observations)
  3. What drives the differences?
  4. What features go together?
  5. How can we categorize groups?

Pre-processing

In this step we first set a seed to make sure our results will be reproducible. We sample 10 items to get a general idea of the dataset and skim to get some descriptives. Then we create a vector with the food labels and two dataframes to be used later. Specifically, the second dataframe we create is a dataset with scaled nutritional characteristics needed for all three unsupervised learning methods used (PCA, K-means, Hierarchical clustering).

set.seed(951)
sample_n(food, 10)

# A tibble: 10 x 17

food_items <- food %>% transmute(inum = row_number(), restaurant, item)
food_labels <- food %>% pull(item)
food_scaled_properties <- food %>% select(calories:calcium) %>% 
    map_df(~ (.x - mean(.x))/sd(.x))

PCA

food_pc <- food_scaled_properties %>% 
    prcomp()

food_pc

pc__scores   <- tidy(food_pc, matrix = "scores")      # Scores
pc_loadings  <- tidy(food_pc, matrix = "loadings")    # Loadings
pc_eigen     <- tidy(food_pc, matrix = "eigenvalues") # Variances

K-means

food_km <- food_scaled_properties %>% 
    kmeans(centers = 3, nstart = 951)
food_km

km_groups   <- augment(food_km, data = food) # Assigned groups
km_clusters <- tidy(food_km)                 # Cluster characteristics
km_metrics  <- glance(food_km)               # Metrics

Hierarchical clustering

food_dist <- food_scaled_properties %>% 
    bind_cols(row_name = food_labels) %>% 
    column_to_rownames("row_name") %>% 
    dist() 

food_hc <- food_dist %>% 
    hclust()

hc_dist <- tidy(food_dist)

Who is most similar in general?

Option 1: PCA - PC1 vs.PC2

food_biplot <- pc__scores %>% 
    filter(PC %in% 1:2) %>% 
    pivot_wider(names_from = PC, names_prefix = "PC", values_from = value) %>% 
    left_join(food_items, by = c("row" = "inum")) %>% 
    ggplot(aes(PC1, PC2, col = restaurant, label = item)) +
    geom_point(alpha = 0.5, show.legend = F)

food_loadings_plot <- pc_loadings %>% 
    filter(PC %in% 1:2) %>% 
        ggplot(aes(value, column, fill = value > 0)) +
    geom_col(show.legend = F) +
    facet_wrap(~PC, ncol = 2)

food_biplot / food_loadings_plot


ggplotly(food_biplot)

Option 2: K-means

km_groups %>% 
    group_by(.cluster) %>% 
    sample_n(10) %>% 
    mutate(row = row_number(), item = str_wrap(item, 30)) %>% 
    ungroup() %>% 
    ggplot(aes(.cluster, row, label = item)) +
    geom_label()

Option 3: Hierarchical clustering

(food_hc %>% 
    fviz_dend(cex = 0.2, k = 10) +
     theme(legend.position = 'none')) %>%
    ggplotly(tooltip = c("labels"))

Option 4: Hierarchical clustering heatmap

food_heatmap <- food_scaled_properties %>% 
    bind_cols(row_name = food_labels) %>% 
    column_to_rownames("row_name") %>% as.matrix()

heatmap(food_heatmap)

Who is most similar to a specific observation?

Distances from hierarchical clustering

Here we examine which entrees are most similar to a Footlong Quarter Pound Coney.

hc_dist %>% 
    filter(item1 == "Footlong Quarter Pound Coney") %>% 
    slice_min(order_by = distance, n = 5) %>% select(item2, distance) %>% 
    left_join(food_items, by = c("item2" = "item"))

# A tibble: 5 x 4
  item2                            distance  inum restaurant 
  <chr>                               <dbl> <int> <chr>      
1 1/2 lb. GrillBurger with Cheese      2.06   154 Dairy Queen
2 1/4 lb. Bacon Cheese GrillBurger     2.21   155 Dairy Queen
3 DQ Ultimate Burger                  2.29   173 Dairy Queen
4 Crispy Chicken Quesadilla            2.37   292 Taco Bell  
5 Roast Turkey, Ranch & Bacon Wrap     2.45   146 Arbys

What drives the differences?

pc_loadings %>% 
    ggplot(aes(value, column, fill = value > 0)) +
    geom_col(show.legend = F) +
    facet_wrap(~PC)

What features go together?

heatmap(food_heatmap)

How to choose the number of clusters?

Look for the elbow.

tibble(centers = 1:15) %>% 
    mutate(model = map(centers, ~ kmeans(food_scaled_properties, .x, nstart = 951))) %>% 
    mutate(tot.withinss = map_dbl(model, ~glance(.x)$tot.withinss)) %>% 
    ggplot(aes(centers, tot.withinss)) +
    geom_line() + geom_point()
